claim: Drinking a glass of lemonade would provide Vitamin C.

supporting.text: Lemons are a natural source of Vitamin C, and lemonade made from real lemons contains this nutrient.

attacks.text: Lemons are a natural source of Vitamin C, and lemonade made from real lemons contains this nutrient.
Many commercial lemonades are made from concentrates or artificial flavors, which may not retain Vitamin C.
Even commercial lemonades often fortify their products with Vitamin C to compensate for nutrient loss during processing.
The amount of Vitamin C in lemonade can vary significantly depending on preparation methods and dilution.
Standard recipes for homemade lemonade typically use enough lemon juice to provide a meaningful amount of Vitamin C.

supporting.text: Vitamin C is water-soluble, so it remains present in the liquid form of lemonade.

attacks.text: Vitamin C is water-soluble, so it remains present in the liquid form of lemonade.
Vitamin C degrades over time, especially when exposed to light and heat, so stored lemonade may lose its Vitamin C content.
Commercial lemonade often contains negligible amounts of real lemon juice, reducing its Vitamin C content significantly.
Even if Vitamin C degrades, freshly prepared lemonade retains sufficient amounts to provide a meaningful dose.

supporting.text: A standard glass of lemonade made with fresh lemon juice typically provides a measurable amount of Vitamin C.

attacks.text: A standard glass of lemonade made with fresh lemon juice typically provides a measurable amount of Vitamin C.
Many commercial lemonades use minimal or no fresh lemon juice, replacing it with artificial flavors and sweeteners, which provide no Vitamin C.
Even in commercial lemonades labeled 'made with real lemon juice,' the Vitamin C content is often negligible due to processing and dilution.
The Vitamin C in fresh lemon juice degrades quickly when exposed to light, heat, or air, reducing its content by the time it is consumed.
Proper storage and preparation (e.g., refrigeration, minimal exposure to air) can preserve most of the Vitamin C in fresh lemon juice.

supporting.text: Nutritional analyses of lemonade confirm the presence of Vitamin C, especially when made from fresh ingredients.

attacks.text: Nutritional analyses of lemonade confirm the presence of Vitamin C, especially when made from fresh ingredients.
Many commercial lemonades contain negligible Vitamin C due to processing and dilution.
Even processed lemonades often include Vitamin C fortification to meet nutritional standards.
Vitamin C degrades rapidly in stored or exposed lemonade, reducing its nutritional benefit.
Proper storage (e.g., refrigeration, airtight containers) can significantly slow Vitamin C degradation.
